title: Centene Stock Plunges After Company Pulls Guidance
excerpt: Managed-care specialist Centene withdrew financial guidance for 2025, warning that earnings will fall well short of expectations. Its shares tumbled. Centene's move comes after industry bellwether UnitedHealth pulled its guidance for the year and replac
text: Centene Stock Plunges After Company Pulls GuidanceManaged-care specialist Centene withdrew financial guidance for 2025, warning that earnings will fall well short of expectations. Its shares tumbled.Centene's move comes after industry bellwether UnitedHealth pulled its guidance for the year and replaced its chief executive. It is likely to add to investors’ nervousness about the entire insurance sector, which has felt the effect of higher-than-expected medical costs. Humana and CVS Health’s Aetna struggled last year, with CVS also bringing on a new CEO.Centene focuses largely on Medicaid and the Affordable Care Act insurance marketplaces. It said it recently got data showing that enrollees in the marketplaces overall appeared fewer, and less healthy, than expected. As a result, the company expects to get a smaller payout from a federal program designed to even out risk across insurers.
html:
Centene Stock Plunges After Company Pulls Guidance

Managed-care specialist Centene withdrew financial guidance for 2025, warning that earnings will fall well short of expectations. Its shares tumbled.

Centene's move comes after industry bellwether UnitedHealth pulled its guidance for the year and replaced its chief executive. It is likely to add to investors’ nervousness about the entire insurance sector, which has felt the effect of higher-than-expected medical costs. Humana and CVS Health’s Aetna struggled last year, with CVS also bringing on a new CEO.

Centene focuses largely on Medicaid and the Affordable Care Act insurance marketplaces. It said it recently got data showing that enrollees in the marketplaces overall appeared fewer, and less healthy, than expected. As a result, the company expects to get a smaller payout from a federal program designed to even out risk across insurers.
